Award.AwardTitle: Astrophysical and Astrochemical Tests of Massive Star Formation Theories
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stars with masses much greater than that of our Sun are the engines that drive the evolution of our galaxy; mixing the interstellar gas and dust with their winds, radiation, and eventually their violent deaths in supernova explosions. This project will improve our understanding of the way in which the most massive of these stars are formed. The project will develop new theoretical and computational models that simulate the formation of these massive stars from their beginnings as condensing core of interstellar hydrogen gas to their birth as the largest stars in our galaxy. These new simulations will include more physically realistic models of the evolution of the proto-stellar core, the surrounding region of rotating infalling matter, and the outflowing winds from the newly forming star. The project will test and verify these models of massive star formation with new observations with state-of-the-art facilities performed at millimeter, sub-millimeter, and mid-infrared wavelengths.

The project will use existing Monte Carlo radiative transfer code for turbulent accreting cores, which the PI has modified to include both dust and gas opacities. These models will be used to extend the canonical evolutionary sequence for massive stars to systematically cover a much larger parameter space of initial core mass, core rotation, and environmental factors. The proposers will also incorporate new models for dust grain alignment and the effects of a binary companion to the current radiative transfer computations. The output of the radiative transfer calculations will consist of observables that can be compared with observations by facilities such as the Atacama Large Millimeter/Sub-millimeter Array (ALMA).

This project will build upon previous efforts by the PI to train of a new generation of scientists, with a strong emphasis on students from underrepresented groups. The project will communicate its results to the public through the development of a presentation entitled ?Birth of the Giants ? the Most Massive Stars in the Universe? to be shown at local schools and at events organized through the Florida Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Massive stars, those with more than 8 times the mass of the Sun, are important for a wide range of processes in the Universe. The goal of this project was to develop theoretical models of massive star formation in the context of the Turbulent Core Accretion paradigm (McKee & Tan 2003), which assume the initial conditions are massive starless gas cores. The models were also to be tested against observations.

The first Intellectual Merit (IM) outcome was the development and public release of a set of theoretical models of massive protostars, including calculation of their continuum emission and total spectral energy distribution (SED) (Zhang & Tan 2018).

The second outcome was testing of these models against new observations made by our group of about 40 massive protostars - ?The SOMA Survey? - with the SOFIA telescope plus archival infrared data (De Buizer et al. 2017; Liu et al. 2019).

The next outcome was extended theoretical modeling of the ionization structure, including associated cm radio emission, and dynamical feedback effects (Tanaka et al. 2016, 2017a, b, 2018). Radio emission of these models was compared to that observed to some SOMA sources by the VLA telescope (Rosero et al. 2019).

The next outcome was astrochemical calculation of the evolution of massive starless cores (Kong et al. 2015; Goodson et al. 2016). These models were compared against ALMA observations of such sources (Tan et al. 2016; Kong et al. 2018).

ALMA was also used to observe some of the SOMA protostars, including the important first dynamical characterization of a massive protostellar binary (Zhang et al. 2019, Nature Astronomy). The Hubble Telescope was also used to observe some of the SOMA sources, including measurement of the ionization fraction in a massive protostellar jet (Fedriani et al. 2019, Nature Communications).

Some Broader Impacts from the work include integration of research results in the teaching and outreach activities of the team members. Several undergraduate and Ph.D. students were also trained as part of the project. Several press releases about the work were released.
